text:
We always ask - ‘Why are talented people leaving India?’

Maybe… this is why.

A CFO from Bharat Petroleum.
A father.
A man who just lost his only daughter at 34.

And even in the darkest moment of his life -
grief wasn’t the only thing he had to fight.

He had to pay bribe after bribe
to simply complete the final rituals of his child.

Ambulance.
Police for FIR & post-mortem.
Crematorium for receipt.
Government office for death certificate.

He writes -
‘I had money, so I paid.
What will the poor do?’

Let that sink in.

When a retired CFO - a person with status, money, connections -
is forced to beg the corrupt system in the middle of the biggest tragedy of his life…

What chance do ordinary people have?

We talk about patriotism.
We talk about ‘New India.’
We talk about Viksit Bharat, global dreams, $5 trillion economy…

But what about the basic dignity of a citizen?

What about a father who is already destroyed once,
and then destroyed again by the system?

Corruption in India doesn’t just steal money.
It steals dignity.
It steals humanity.
It steals trust in the country we call home.

People aren’t leaving India just for salaries.
They’re leaving for basic respect, fairness, empathy.

We don’t need rocket science reforms.
We need compassion.
Accountability.
A system that doesn’t profit from someone’s pain.

If a nation cannot stand beside a parent when they are burying their child…

What hope is left?

Rape.
A crime that destroys a life forever.

But in India, do you know what destroys that pain even more?

A price tag.

This video shows a cop allegedly taking ₹2 lakh to remove someone’s name from a gangrape case.

Not proof. Not justice.
Just cash.

And this is not a ‘one-off incident.’
This is the system we are told to trust.
This is the reality we are forced to live in.

Here’s the obvious question:

If money can erase crimes like gangrape…
What is the value of a woman’s dignity in this country?
Just ₹2 lakh?

We demand women to ‘speak up.’
We blame them for ‘not reporting.’
But who will they report to…
When the protectors have become the predators of justice?

Corruption is not just about money.
It is about lives destroyed in silence.
It is about criminals walking free with a smile.
It is about victims reliving their trauma every single day.

India doesn’t need new slogans.
India doesn’t need new committees.
India needs accountability.
India needs a system where rich criminals don’t get VIP justice…

and poor victims don’t get endless pain.

If you are reading this, please remember: Sometimes the monster isn’t hiding in the dark. Sometimes he’s sitting in uniform… behind a desk.

Speak. Share. Demand better. Because silence isn’t going to save our daughters and sisters.

My simple principle for a happy and peaceful life -

The only time I look into someone's cup is to make sure they have enough, not to check if mine is fuller.

‘Gen Z doesn’t want to struggle.’
No - Gen Z refuses to be exploited.

Saw a post where someone complained that a Gen Z employee demanded extra pay for extra hours… and walked out when he didn’t get it.

And somehow that became a problem?

Let’s get this straight:

Boomers: ‘Work 14 hours. Don’t complain. Be grateful.’
Millennials: ‘At least we’ll get promoted in 5 years.’
Gen Z: ‘Pay me for my time. Respect my boundaries. And don’t treat burnout like a badge of honor.’

And suddenly, we’re ‘entitled.’

Why is asking for:
• Fair pay → entitlement?
• Work-life balance → lack of commitment?
• Mental health → weakness?
• Basic respect → no ‘work ethic’?

Maybe the mindset has changed because the world has changed.
Because loyalty doesn’t pay rent anymore.
Because ‘struggle’ isn’t a personality trait.
Because we saw our parents sacrifice health, happiness & family for companies that replaced them in 2 weeks.

Gen Z isn’t running away from hard work.
They’re running away from toxic work.

If valuing boundaries = irresponsible…
If refusing free labour = laziness…
If knowing your worth = attitude…

Then yes, Gen Z is proudly guilty.

The generational gap isn’t about work ethic.
It’s about self-respect.

Ghar pe sabji apni pasand ki banwa nahi paa rahe hai.

New Update in Corporate Surveillance:

If you don’t touch your keyboard for 5 minutes… congratulations, you’re now ‘idle.’

If you dare to remain human for 15 minutes… you’re marked as ‘engaged in activities away from the system.’

Yes. That’s an actual update from Cognizant’s new monitoring system.

And honestly, this says a lot about where corporate culture is heading.

We say we want:

Productivity
Creativity
Innovation
Ownership
Accountability
Mental wellbeing

But we’re designing systems that track… mouse movement.

When did ‘trust’ get replaced with ‘tracking’?
When did ‘output’ get replaced with ‘keyboard strokes’?
And when did ‘employee’ get replaced with ‘activity log ID: 29833’?

Here’s the funny part:
Some of the best ideas come when you’re NOT typing.
When you’re thinking.
When you’re reflecting.
When you’re discussing.
When you’re breathing.

But now, apparently, if you take a washroom break, stretch, blink too slowly, or dare to think without touching the mouse, you’re ‘away from system.’

Maybe next update will be:
‘Employee did not exhale for 2 minutes - mark as unproductive.’
‘Employee’s heartbeat dropped - possible laziness detected.’
‘Employee looked out of the window - termination under progress.’

The future of work is NOT about counting seconds of stillness.
It’s about measuring real impact.
Real output.
Real value.

And trust me - no great company was ever built on micromanagement or fear.

Employees don’t leave companies.
Employees leave ‘monitoring systems’ disguised as culture.

If organisations want loyalty, innovation, and retention…
They need to stop treating people like machines.

Because here’s a truth no system can track:

A trusted employee always outperforms a monitored one.

I don't know why people hate Gen Z so much.

We are so honest.

Aap likhte hoge ki chutti chahiye - beemar hu and all.

We speak the truth.

Chutti chahiye.

Manager asks ‘Kyu?’

We say -

Break up ho gaya.
Vibe nahi ho paa raha hai.
I am tired.
Mental break chahiye.
Shopping jaana hai.
pichle week zyada kaam kar liya tha.

The people who are the most jealous of this - Boomers.

They're like - Haww, aisa kaisa?

‘Jabb mere chacha ji ki death Hui thi, uss dinn bhi maina kaam kiya tha’

‘Mere shaadi Wale dinn, subha bhi I worked - raat ko hi thi na shaadi’

Bruh.
This is not a thing to show off.

Take breaks please, nothing increases productivity more than this.

Sometimes just wonder and sit - Main kaam karr kyu raha hu? Taaki I can enjoy life.

- I can attend my best friend's wedding.
- I can roam the world.
- I can afford things for the people I love.

Pleaseeeee don't make WORK your entire personality.

At least I don't need to revive my dada, dadi, chacha, chachi etc for each job - taaki I can get a leave.

An honest LinkedIn update would look like this:

‘Bought my first house today.
Thanks to the brands who paid me…
…to sell you the dream of buying a course that changed my life.’

Reality:
Courses changed something -
Their EMI status.

Job hunting in India is not for the weak.

You’ll see a post that says ‘We’re urgently hiring!’
You apply in 30 seconds.
And they ghost you faster than your ex.

‘Easy Apply’ feels like Tinder.
You swipe, they ignore.
And somewhere, HR writes - ‘We’ll get back to you.’

You update your resume 47 times, change fonts, remove hobbies, add buzzwords like ‘team player’, ‘growth mindset’, and ‘Excel wizard’…
Still no reply.
Meanwhile on LinkedIn:
People with 2 connections and 0 experience write -
‘I’m thrilled to announce I’ve joined Google.’
And you’re sitting there thinking -
Maybe I should be ‘thrilled’ to announce that I’m still unemployed.

But here’s the truth:
You’re not lazy.
You’re not behind.
You’re just living in a country where ‘experience required: 3 years’ comes in intern listings.
So hang in there.

Because one day, you’ll get that offer.
And your ‘We’re happy to have you onboard’ email will feel like a national award.

I sometimes hate how we only post ‘happy’ moments here and I have always wanted to change it.

So, I am going to start with myself.

No, I didn't get a new job, cracked a new company, got 7 figure salaries etc.

I just want to normalize being ‘not delighted/excited’ all the time.

We live in a world where everyone is ‘grateful’, ‘honoured’, and ‘thrilled’.
But rarely do you see - ‘tired’, ‘lost’, or ‘unsure’.

We all are humans, and we all feel things - not all days are good.

You know what’s truly rare on LinkedIn?
Someone saying: ‘I don’t have it figured out, but I’m still trying.’

So, here I am -

I am not doing great, have been fighting - 1 day at a time. I think I will get through it :)

There's nothing more motivational than being myself for me :)

On LinkedIn, everyone is humble, grateful and blessed.

In real life, half of them won't even hold the elevator door for you.

We spend half our lives thinking -
‘Once I get there, I’ll be happy.’

 But there is no ‘there.’
 Every goal you hit shifts the finish line.
 Maybe the real success is not in arrival,
 but in learning to love the walk - even when it’s uphill.

For years, I chased every milestone.
 💼 Bigger title
 💰 Higher salary
 📈 Better company
 🏙️ Fancy city

But every time I achieved one, I felt... nothing.

Just a few days of excitement, followed by the same emptiness again.
Then one day, I asked myself -
‘What if I stopped chasing and started living?’
So I did.

I stopped trying to ‘impress.’
Started learning slowly.
Started eating better.
Started walking without earphones.
Started saying ‘no.’
Started choosing peace over people.
And the irony?

The moment I stopped chasing success - it started finding me.
 Better work.
 Calmer mind.
 Real people.
 Healthier body.

Because when you stop running after what you think you want, life finally gives you what you actually need.

If you’ve been feeling exhausted lately - maybe it’s not burnout.
Maybe your soul just wants a break from pretending.

When one airline collapses… the others show their true colours.
And unfortunately, it’s not humanity. It’s pricing strategy.

With IndiGo flights getting cancelled across sectors, thousands of passengers are stranded, panicking, and scrambling for alternatives.
And what did the other airlines do?

Quietly increase fares.
Not by ₹500… but by ₹5,000–₹10,000+ in some routes.

Look at Delhi → Mumbai today:

The same flights that were ₹5k–₹6k last week are suddenly ₹24k–₹25k+.
No festival.
No surge in fuel cost.
Just people in trouble - and a perfect opportunity to profit.

I know business is business.
But sometimes, basic humanity > revenue targets.

Imagine families trying to get home.
Students.
People travelling for medical emergencies.
Or someone who simply cannot afford a last-minute 2x fare overnight.

In moments like these, industries show what they’re truly made of.

A little empathy won’t kill the quarterly numbers.
But it might restore faith in the system.

We need pricing regulations during crises.
We need accountability.
We need humanity.

Because when airlines turn a crisis into a revenue opportunity…
it’s not ‘dynamic pricing’.
It’s just disappointing.

Presenting my 2025 LinkedIn Wrapped:

Messages I replied to immediately: 2
Messages I replied to after 7 days with ‘Sorry, missed this’: 143
Messages I saw, ignored, and still lost sleep over: 89

Recruiters who said ‘Your profile is impressive, let’s connect’: 27
Recruiters who vanished after I replied: all 27

People who endorsed me for skills I don’t even have: 11
People I endorsed out of guilt: 11

Webinars I registered for: 52
Webinars I actually attended: 0
Webinars I left running just for the certificate: 8

Times I opened LinkedIn for motivation: 34
Times I left LinkedIn feeling useless: 34

Posts I wrote from the heart: 7
Posts that went viral: 0
Posts I wrote in anger at 2 AM that surprisingly went viral: 1

People who said ‘Let’s grab coffee sometime’: 19
Actual coffees grabbed: 0
Times I grabbed coffee alone while thinking about my life: 47

Times I said ‘Let’s connect offline’: 13
Times I meant it: … let’s skip this one.

Meetings that could’ve been an email: 96
Emails that could’ve been nothing: 41
‘Quick sync?’ messages that ruined my entire day: 57

LinkedIn Wrapped 2025 taught me only one thing:
We’re all pretending to have our life together,
and honestly… we deserve an award for acting.

Corporate Facts That Hurt More Than Breakups 💔😂
Fact 1:
People don’t leave companies.
Companies leave people unread.

Fact 2:
‘Let’s have a quick call’ has destroyed more peace than any heartbreak ever has.

Fact 3:
Your performance review depends more on your manager’s mood than your actual performance.

Fact 4:
You don’t need an alarm clock.
You have anxiety.

Fact 5:
90% of ‘urgent’ tasks magically stop being urgent after 6 pm.
And the saddest fact?
You can go from ‘We are a family’ to ‘Your access has been removed’ in 0.2 seconds.

If you relate, come sit.
We cry on weekdays and revive on weekends.

The kind of partner we all deserve + The kind of manager that approves such leaves :)

Another uncomfortable thought:
If work is your entire personality, then you’re not living - you’re being utilised.
Some people don’t experience time.

They consume it in slots.
Even rest is ‘well-deserved’.
Even joy needs justification.

They don’t sit with thoughts.
They schedule them.

The tragedy isn’t working hard.
The tragedy is outsourcing meaning to a payslip.

Philosophers warned us about this long ago -
when identity collapses into function, humans become tools that applaud their own usefulness.

Titles feel permanent until they aren’t.
Calendars feel important until they stop filling themselves.

And when work finally goes quiet - layoffs, burnout, weekends, retirement -
there’s a strange silence no KPI prepares you for.

Because if you only know how to be productive,
you don’t know how to be present.

Work should sharpen you.
Not replace you.

A life that cannot slow down
is not ambitious -
it’s afraid of stillness.
